nytimes_articles.abstract: Bankers' Hours   Q.  Many suburban banks are open until 6 P.M., if not later, and often on Saturdays. Why are banks in New York City, the world's financial capital, locked up at 3 P.M. each day?

nytimes_articles.headline: Unheralded Maryland Jolts UMass
nytimes_articles.abstract: The season's high expectations came crashing down on the University of Massachusetts today.   Using relentless defensive pressure, scintillating shooting and another strong inside performance by Joe Smith, the unheralded Maryland Terrapins shocked the second-seeded Minutemen, 95-87, in the second major upset of the Midwest Regional. On Friday, U.C.L.A., once ranked No. 1 in the nation, was upended by Tulsa, 112-102.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jaclyn Honig, Andrew Schreiber
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jaclyn Honig, a daughter of Lewis and Della Honig of New York, is to be married today to Andrew Alan Schreiber, the son of Frank and June Schreiber, also of New York. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey is to perform the ceremony at the Rainbow Room's Pavilion in New York.   The bride is the marketing manager at United Beauty Products in New York, a retail and wholesale concern of which her father is the president and her mother, the financial officer. The bride graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology.

nytimes_articles.headline: Massacre at Hebron Exposes Anti-American Mood in Israel
nytimes_articles.abstract: In some Israeli circles, a new dirty word has popped up in the last few weeks: Brooklyn.   Brooklyn produced Benjamin C. Goldstein, who as Baruch Goldstein of the Qiryat Arba settlement massacred at least 29 Palestinians in Hebron three weeks ago. And Brooklyn, of course, is part of the United States. That has been enough to touch a certain anti-American streak that lies just below the surface for many Israelis.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art Advocates Troop to Albany to Seek a Piece of the Pie
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS thick as the fog rising from the melting snow, the lobbyists arrive here each March, bringing their fact sheets and well-honed pleas. Heeding the maxim, "Those who don't ask, don't get," they swarm through the state capital at budget time.   Among the recent throngs were advocates of the arts from Westchester County, who took part in a day of campaigning sponsored by the Alliance of New York State Arts Councils, based in Spring Valley. Vying for elevator space with American Legionnaires, 4-H clubbers and a host of others, they made the rounds of legislative offices, asking members of the Westchester delegation to the capital to approve more spending for the arts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hotels Adding New Airline Links
nytimes_articles.abstract: Holiday Inn has begun offering frequent flier miles on American Airlines for stays at its hotels worldwide.   The arrangement, effective last month, provides 2.5 miles to American Airlines AAdvantage members for each dollar spent on a room at a standard corporate rate or higher, whether or not the guest used the airline to get to the hotel.

nytimes_articles.headline: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
nytimes_articles.abstract: NOBODY NOWHERE: The Extraordinary Autobiography of an Autistic By Donna Williams. Avon, $10. The author describes the tortured inner world she lived in for years, unable to accept human contact and yet longing for it. Detailing her fitful progress toward an independent life and also including advice for families of autistic people, the book offers "fascinating testimony to an intelligence undimmed by mental turmoil," Daniel Goleman said here last year.  OPERATION SHYLOCK: A Confession By Philip Roth. Vintage International, $12. In this novel, a writer who just happens to be named Philip Roth and who is recovering from a breakdown discovers that another man is impersonating him quite successfully in Israel. His confrontation with his doppelganger forms the substance of the plot, which involves both men in Israeli politics and a debate over the future of the Jews. Last year our reviewer, D. M. Thomas, said: "Despite the seriousness of its theme, the book carries the feeling of creative joy. One feels that Mr. Roth feels that he's let rip." Vintage has also reissued two of the author's earlier books, both with autobiographical elements. MY LIFE AS A MAN ($11) concerns the obsessive and disastrous early marriage of a writer named Peter Tarnopol. Mr. Roth "can be not only funny but lyrical," Morris Dickstein said here in 1974. GOODBYE, COLUMBUS: And Five Short Stories ($11), Mr. Roth's first book, comprises the now famous love affair of Neil Klugman and Brenda Patimkin, as well as various meditations on American Jewish life. In 1959 The New York Times's reviewer, William Peden, called the author "a keen recorder of an indecisive generation."

nytimes_articles.headline: Sun City Builder Mounting a South Carolina Venture
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Del Webb Corporation, builder of several large retirement communities in the West, has embarked on its first project in the East: a 5,100-acre, 8,000-detached-home development near this coastal Carolina community 12 miles west of Hilton Head Island.   The $110 million project is considered a major boost to this state's southeastern sector, known as Lowcountry, a region facing an uncertain future with the imminent closing of the Charleston Naval Base. Government leaders say the project is as vital an economic stimulus for that area as the $300 million BMW Manufacturing Corporation plant is for the northwestern industrial quadrant of the state.

nytimes_articles.headline: FOCUS ON DOCTORS AND EXECUTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Controversy over the participation of doctors in executions has led four leading medical and human rights groups to recommend changes in state and Federal laws to insure that they do not require physicians to violate professional ethics.   After reviewing each state's laws and regulations on executions, the groups reported that executions often required doctors to violate professional ethics.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wild Pitch By Selig
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   The article by Bud Selig ("Baseball's 'Best Interest' Phrasing Best Viewed Narrowly," The Times, March 6) lacked balance and was self-serving.

nytimes_articles.headline: White Outrage, Black Suspicion
nytimes_articles.abstract: It has been common knowledge since the days of the Kerner Commission that in many respects we are two societies -- one black and one white. One of those respects is the vastly different way in which our two societies react to events on the cultural edge between them, like the debate over the proper response to the vicious remarks of Khalid Abdul Muhammad, the Nation of Islam spokesman, at Kean College and elsewhere.    Simply put, black people and white people of good conscience -- even those with equal levels of education and wealth -- see events very differently. This was true during the trial of the youths accused of the assault and rape of a jogger in Central Park in 1989, during the recent controversy over the preservation of the African Burial Ground in lower Manhattan, and in the aftermath of the 1991 Crown Heights riots. And it is starkly true in the current debate over the Nation of Islam's failure to respond adequately to Mr. Muhammad's speech.

nytimes_articles.headline: Grange Vote: Move It
nytimes_articles.abstract: The proposed move and restoration of the Hamilton Grange won a critical endorsement on Thursday when Community Board 9 voted 18 to 11 in favor. The vote capped months of bitter debate among preservationists and residents of the area.   The National Park Service will now seek $10.6 million in Federal funds to move the building from its current site -- 287 Convent Avenue at West 141st Street -- a block away to St. Nicholas Park, and fully restore it. United States Representative Charles B. Rangel supports the project and is a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sarah Case, Leonard Wright
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sarah Case, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald K. Case of Peekskill, N.Y., was married on Friday to Leonard T. Wright, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard T. Wright of Clifton Park, N.Y. Donald McGrath, a marriage officer in Philipstown, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Xaviar's Restaurant in Garrison, N.Y.   Mrs. Wright, 25, graduated from Syracuse University. Her father is an artist. Her mother, Bonnie Case, owns Case & Company, a women's fashion and sweater manufacturer in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Envisioning the Future Of Liberty State Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: A recent letter to the New Jersey editor about Liberty State Park said that opponents of a golf course have a "do-nothing plan except leave it an unused wasteland for another 30 years." Actually, the Central Park concept for Liberty State Park's central area has been well publicized for over a year and has strong support from the vast majority of area residents as well as a variety of statewide recreational and environmental organizations.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
MUSIC FROM PRAGUE

The Stamic Quartet of Prague makes its regional debut today in the Music at Hillwood series at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville. The quartet was founded in 1985. 

In the concert at 3 P.M., the group, with Caroline Stoessinger, pianist and artistic director of the series, and a tenor, Paul Grove, will perform works by Dvorak, Haas, Martinu and Mozart (626-3100).

nytimes_articles.headline: Journal; Reality Bites Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: After several years of trying to avoid Generation X, which has been much too sweatily trying to upstage my own boomer generation in the popular press, I finally succumbed last weekend by going to see "Reality Bites." This is the movie that has been both praised as the last word on X-ers and damned as Hollywood's slickest effort yet to exploit them -- which makes it this year's answer to "The Graduate," the 1967 classic that either summed up my generation or caricatured it for big bucks.   "Reality Bites," like "The Graduate," is a funny movie. But isn't it telling the same story? Once again a bright but alienated recent college graduate mopes about, unable or unwilling to find a job or a reason to exist. A pretty, somewhat more directed young woman must choose between the alienated hero and a square go-getter. A scowling father reprimands his child: "I'll tell you the problem with your generation -- you don't have any work ethic." And everyone smokes a lot even when they haven't just finished having sex.

nytimes_articles.headline: With a Rash of New Clubs, It's Survival of the Fitness
nytimes_articles.abstract: For several months now, Chelsea residents have been deluged with fliers, signs and direct-mail promotions selling the body beautiful and healthful. This winter alone, three new fitness clubs have opened in the neighborhood. In fact, with a total of 14 health clubs in Chelsea and its Flatiron fringes, the area now has the largest concentration in the city, club owners say.   The Chelsea gym wars could put to shame the Upper West Side skirmish of two years ago, when two giant clubs around Lincoln Center, Equinox and World Gym, vied to recruit trainers and members with appealing prices and much publicity. Several small clubs in the area reported losing business, and one closed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Inquiry Reported at Kings County Hospital
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office has opened an investigation into the reconstruction of Kings County Hospital Center, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.   Over 10 years the cost of reconstructing the city hospital, which serves much of central Brooklyn, has grown to an estimated $1 billion from an initial figure of $50 million. Last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered a moratorium on the project.

nytimes_articles.headline:
A LA CARTE;
A Taste of Nostalgia (With Mashed Potatoes)
nytimes_articles.abstract:
NOSTALGIA for the 1940's and 50's inspired Ethel's Sunday Dinner, a new restaurant in East Rutherford opened by Buddy and Ken Gebhardt. Next door to Park & Orchard, the brothers' well-known, hangar-sized restaurant with a natural foods theme, this unlikely offshoot seats only 34 diners and specializes in comfort foods with an emphasis on red meat.

Pot roast, meatloaf and roasted chicken -- all in oversized portions and accompanied by a buttery mound of mashed potatoes -- are typical of the hearty main courses. Desserts include banana cream pie, an icebox cake of chocolate wafers and whipped cream, and a pudding of the day like tapioca, rice or butterscotch.

Buddy Gebhardt said that the restaurant was named Ethel after their mother, and that the concept was inspired by memories of Sunday dinners that she and other relatives prepared during their childhood in northern New Jersey. Keeping it in the family, the chef is Lenny Maiorano, a brother-in-law who has cooked at Park & Orchard for the last five years.

Construction glitches delayed the opening, Mr. Gebhardt said, from the planned November date until March 2. The opening coincided with the region's 15th winter storm, Mr. Maiorano said, and only 13 customers showed up.

The restaurant, which is in part of a brick building that formerly housed a nuts and bolts factory, is decorated in a 50's period look with floral print draperies, yellow and green marble tile floor and striped banquettes. 

Main courses are $16.95 to $21.95, including vegetables and a salad platter. There is no liquor license; diners bring their own wine. Wine can also be bought at Park & Orchard, which has one of the state's premier cellars, and brought over. The restaurant is open Wednesday through Sunday from 5 to 10 P.M.

Ethel's Sunday Dinner, 246 Hackensack Street, East Rutherford. (201) 896-1333.
Irish Specialties

 The crush of St. Patrick's Day is past, but many Irish-Americans and kindred spirits continue to head to the Harp 'n' Bard, a snug Irish pub and restaurant in Clifton. With entertainment several nights a week by the likes of Kevin McArdle and his band or Mike Byrne and the Green Derby Boys, many customers sing along or do a turn on the pocket-sized dance floor.

Beers on draft include Guinness Stout, Harp, John Courage and Newcastle Brown Ale and sold by the pint and half pint. The kitchen offers simple fare like hamburgers and even veal parmigiana, but the better bets are the traditional Irish dishes.

Shepherd's pie, ground lamb and peas in gravy baked under a cap of mashed potatoes; fish in a thick batter with chips (french fries) and malt vinegar, and a mixed grill of slightly charred pork chop, Irish bacon, imported sausages and black and white puddings with a grilled tomato are typical.

These entrees are $8.95 to $10.95. The price includes either a ho-hum iceberg lettuce salad or a creamy and fortifying potato soup speckled with bacon bits. To finish, whisky-laced Irish coffee with whipped cream beats the desserts.

There's a dart board in a corner of the bar, and old wooden booths separated by lace cafe curtains ring the dining area. Some of the staff speak with an Irish lilt and remain cordial despite the crush.

The pub is open for lunch Tuesday through Friday and for dinner every day. Live entertainment is offered Friday through Sunday.

Next door, at the Harp and Shamrock, a gift shop under the same ownership, Irish food specialties are also available.

Harp 'n' Bard, 363 Lakeview Avenue, Clifton. (201) 772-7282.
Dinners With Themes

 The Fresh Fields Cafe, a trim and easygoing storefront restaurant in a Chatham shopping center, is now offering a choice of seven prix fixe meals in addition to its regular menu of contemporary American fare. The three-course dinners, with themes like Marseilles, Milan and low calorie, range from $24 to $26 and should appeal to value-conscious diners.

The chef-owner, Kevin Collins, and his sous-chef, Thomas Arrasate, work out of a closet-sized kitchen in view of the diners and specialize in eclectic dishes accompanied by a signature garden patch of vegetables.

The Milan dinner includes grilled eggplant and pepper salad in balsamic vinaigrette, risotto with Gorgonzola and a choice of homemade dessert. Marseilles includes mussels in saffron sauce, salmon fillet in lemon and herb sauce and dessert. A typical low-calorie menu comprises Fresh Fields salad (mixed greens, alfalfa sprouts and fruit), a grilled fish of the day with lemon and herb sauce, and a fruit plate. 

As for the health-conscious fare, Mr. Collins says he offers the low- calorie meals because so many people talk about their health problems and special diets. "But," he said, "to be honest with you, we only sell about five low-cal dinners a week. You'd think everybody would jump on it, but they don't." 

The Morris County restaurant, which is convenient for pretheater dining before performances at Drew University, does not have a liquor license. It is open for lunch Tuesday through Friday from noon to 2 P.M. and for dinner, Tuesday through Saturday from 5:30 to 10 P.M. and Sunday from 4 to 9 P.M. 

Fresh Fields Cafe, Hickory Square Shopping Center, 641 Shunpike Road, Chatham. (201) 377-4072.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Could These Rangers Be Self-Destructing?
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS the Rangers approached the Stanley Cup playoffs in other years, positive X-rays were their negatives. X-rays of Brian Leetch's ankle fractured on sidewalk ice last year, on Toronto ice four years ago. X-rays in earlier years of Ulf Nilsson's fractured ankle, of Dale Rolfe's fractured ankle and of Jean Ratelle's fractured ankle.   But two years ago the Rangers were frosted by Adam Graves's suspension for slashing Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins in the playoffs.
